pull.title: depends: default to using GCC tool wrappers for LTO (with GCC)
pull.body:
This improves support for LTO by using gcc wrappers for `ar`, `nm`, `ranlib`,
that correctly setup plugin arguments for LTO, when using GCC.

Other HOSTS are using clang.

Portion of #25391.

Guix Build (x86_64):
```bash
```

Guix Build (arm64):
```bash
```

events.body: Are `NM` and `RANLIB` set/used somewhere in our `configure.ac`?

rename.from: build: default to using GCC tool wrappers for LTO
rename.to: depends: default to using GCC tool wrappers for LTO (with GCC)

events.body: Rebased, and changed the approach here, so we are no-longer modifying defaults, or need to touch configure.

> Rebased, and changed the approach here, so we are no-longer modifying defaults, or need to touch configure.

Wrt this new approach, why these 3 hosts only are modified? What about other hosts?

> Wrt this new approach, why these 3 hosts only are modified? What about other hosts?

The other HOSTS are all using Clang.

With the following diff:
```diff
--- a/configure.ac
+++ b/configure.ac
@@ -2049,5 +2049,6 @@ echo "  CPPFLAGS        = $DEBUG_CPPFLAGS $HARDENED_CPPFLAGS $CORE_CPPFLAGS $CPP
 echo "  CXX             = $CXX"
 echo "  CXXFLAGS        = $LTO_CXXFLAGS $DEBUG_CXXFLAGS $HARDENED_CXXFLAGS $WARN_CXXFLAGS $NOWARN_CXXFLAGS $ERROR_CXXFLAGS $GPROF_CXXFLAGS $CORE_CXXFLAGS $CXXFLAGS"
 echo "  LDFLAGS         = $LTO_LDFLAGS $PTHREAD_LIBS $HARDENED_LDFLAGS $GPROF_LDFLAGS $CORE_LDFLAGS $LDFLAGS"
+echo "  AR              = $AR"
 echo "  ARFLAGS         = $ARFLAGS"
 echo
```

it is easy to see the wrong `AR` variable value:
```
...
  LTO             = yes

  target os       = mingw32
  build os        = linux-gnu

  CC              = /usr/bin/ccache x86_64-w64-mingw32-gcc
  CFLAGS          = -pthread -pipe -std=c11 -flto -O2 
  CPPFLAGS        =  -fmacro-prefix-map=$(abs_top_srcdir)=.  -U_FORTIFY_SOURCE -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2  -DHAVE_BUILD_INFO -D_MT -DWIN32 -D_WINDOWS -D_WIN32_WINNT=0x0601 -D_WIN32_IE=0x0501 -DWIN32_LEAN_AND_MEAN -DNOMINMAX -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -DPROVIDE_FUZZ_MAIN_FUNCTION -I/home/hebasto/git/bitcoin/depends/x86_64-w64-mingw32/include/ 
  CXX             = /usr/bin/ccache x86_64-w64-mingw32-g++-posix -std=c++17
  CXXFLAGS        =  -flto  -fdebug-prefix-map=$(abs_top_srcdir)=.  -fstack-reuse=none -Wstack-protector -fstack-protector-all -fcf-protection=full      -fno-extended-identifiers -pipe -std=c++17 -flto -O2 
  LDFLAGS         =  -flto -lpthread  -Wl,--enable-reloc-section -Wl,--dynamicbase -Wl,--nxcompat -Wl,--high-entropy-va -pie   -Wl,--major-subsystem-version -Wl,6 -Wl,--minor-subsystem-version -Wl,1 -flto -L/home/hebasto/git/bitcoin/depends/x86_64-w64-mingw32/lib 
  AR              = /usr/bin/x86_64-w64-mingw32-ar
  ARFLAGS         = cr

```

Suggesting to rebase this branch on top of the https://github.com/hebasto/bitcoin/commits/220718-pathtool.

### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#25573](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25573) ([POC] guix: produce a fully -static-pie x86_64 bitcoind using GCC and glibc by fanquake)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.

issue.title: [POC] guix: produce a fully `-static-pie` bitcoind
issue.body:
Use Guix to produce a fully `-static-pie` `x86_64-linux-gnu` & `aarch64-linux-gnu` bitcoind using GCC 12.3.0 and glibc 2.38. The binary is ~15mb stripped, includes wallet/upnp/natpmp/zmq etc, and is built using LTO. This builds on #25391 and #27897.

```bash
# file bitcoind
	ELF 64-bit LSB pie executable, x86-64, version 1 (GNU/Linux), static-pie linked, for GNU/Linux 3.2.0, stripped

# ldd bitcoind
	statically linked

# ls -la bitcoind
	14831792 bitcoind
```

Using glibc for static builds, would be less of a leap compared to switching to musl libc (POC in #23203).

So far I've tested the binary, including `test_bitcoin`, on a few different systems:
* Ubuntu 22.04 with glibc 2.35 (latest glibc release)
* Ubuntu 18.04 with glibc 2.27
* Ubuntu 16.04 with glibc 2.24
* CentOS 7 with glibc 2.17 (which is lower than our current minimum required of 2.18)
* CentOS 8 with glibc 2.28
* Alpine 3.16 with musl libc 1.2.3 (latest musl libc release)
* Alpine 3.12 with musl libc 1.1.24

I've also performed a full sync to the current tip (height=744166), and had the node running for a few days:

[`-static-pie`](https://gcc.gnu.org/onlinedocs/gcc/Link-Options.html)
> Produce a static position independent executable on targets that support it.
A static position independent executable is similar to a static executable,
but can be loaded at any address without a dynamic linker.
